Standard_Text: Condense clauses in a variety of ways (e.g., through various types of embedded clauses and other ways of condensing as in, There was a Gold Rush. It began in the 1850s. It brought a lot of people to California. → The Gold Rush that began in the 1850s brought a lot of people to California) to create precise and detailed sentences.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Condense clauses in an increasing variety of ways (e.g., through a growing number of embedded clauses and other condensing, as in, The dog ate quickly. The dog choked. → The dog ate so quickly that it choked) to create precise and detailed sentences.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Condense clauses in simple ways (e.g., through simple embedded clauses, as in, The woman is a doctor. She helps children. → The woman is a doctor who helps children) to create precise and detailed sentences.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Condensing ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Combine clauses in a wide variety of ways (e.g., creating complex sentences using a variety of subordinate conjunctions) to make connections between and join ideas, for example, to express cause/effect (e.g., Since the lion was at the waterhole, the deer ran away), to make a concession, or to link two ideas that happen at the same time (e.g., The cubs played while their mother hunted).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Combine clauses in an increasing variety of ways (e.g., creating complex sentences using familiar subordinate conjunctions) to make connections between and join ideas in sentences, for example, to express cause/effect (e.g., The deer ran because the mountain lion came) or to make a concession (e.g., She studied all night even though she wasn't feeling well).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Combine clauses in a few basic ways to make connections between and join ideas in sentences (e.g., creating compound sentences using coordinate conjunctions, such as and, but, so).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Connecting ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Connecting and Condensing Ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand sentences with a variety of adverbials (e.g., adverbs, adverb phrases, prepositional phrases) to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause, and so on) about a variety of familiar and new activities and processes (e.g., They worked quietly all night in their room).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand sentences with a growing variety of adverbials (e.g., adverbs, prepositional phrases) to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause, and so on) about a familiar or new activity or process (e.g., They worked quietly. They ran across the soccer field).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand sentences with familiar adverbials (e.g., basic prepositional phrases) to provide details (e.g., time, manner, place, cause, and so on) about a familiar activity or process (e.g., They walked to the soccer field).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Modifying to add details
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in an increasing variety of ways (e.g., adding general academic adjectives and adverbs to noun phrases or more complex clause embedding) in order to enrich the meaning of sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in a variety of ways (e.g., adding adjectives to noun phrases or simple clause embedding) in order to enrich the meaning of sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expand noun phrases in simple ways (e.g., adding an adjective) in order to enrich the meaning of sentences and add details about ideas, people, things, and so on.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Using nouns and noun phrases
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use various verbs/verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) and tenses appropriate to the task and text type (e.g., timeless present for science explanation, mixture of past and present for historical information report) for a variety of familiar and new topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use various verbs/verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) and tenses appropriate to the task, text type, and discipline (e.g., simple past for retelling, timeless present for science explanation) for an increasing variety of familiar and new topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use various verbs/verb types (e.g., doing, saying, being/having, thinking/feeling) and tenses appropriate to the text type and discipline (e.g., simple past for recounting an experience) for familiar topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Using verbs and verb phrases
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expanding and Enriching Ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply increasing understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using an increasing variety of academic connecting and transitional words or phrases (e.g., for instance, in addition, at the end) to comprehending texts and writing cohesive texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply increasing understanding of language resources for referring the reader back or forward in text (e.g., how pronouns, synonyms, or nominalizations refer back to nouns in text) to comprehending texts and writing cohesive texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply growing understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using a variety of connecting words or phrases (e.g., since, next, for example) to comprehending texts and writing texts with increasing cohesion.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply growing understanding of language resources for referring the reader back or forward in text (e.g., how pronouns or synonyms refer back to nouns in text) to comprehending texts and writing texts with increasing cohesion.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply basic understanding of how ideas, events, or reasons are linked throughout a text using everyday connecting words or phrases (e.g., first, yesterday) to comprehending texts and writing basic texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply basic understanding of language resources for referring the reader back or forward in text (e.g., how pronouns refer back to nouns in text) to comprehending texts and writing basic texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Understanding cohesion
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how different text types are organized to express ideas (e.g., how a narrative is organized sequentially with predictable stages versus how opinions/arguments are structured logically, grouping related ideas) to comprehending texts and writing cohesive texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply increasing understanding of how different text types are organized to express ideas (e.g., how a narrative is organized sequentially with predictable stages versus how an explanation is organized around ideas) to comprehending texts and writing texts with increasing cohesion.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Apply understanding of how different text types are organized to express ideas (e.g., how a narrative is organized sequentially) to comprehending texts and writing basic texts.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Understanding text structure
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Structuring Cohesive Texts
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Learning About How English Works
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Select a variety of appropriate affixes for accuracy and precision (e.g., She's walking. I'm uncomfortable. They left reluctantly).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a wide variety of general academic and domain-specific words, synonyms, antonyms, and figurative language to create precision and shades of meaning while speaking and writing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Select a growing number of frequently used affixes for accuracy and precision (e.g., She walked. He likes…, I'm unhappy).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a growing number of general academic and domain-specific words, synonyms, and antonyms to create precision and shades of meaning while speaking and writing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Select a few frequently used affixes for accuracy and precision (e.g., She walks, I'm unhappy).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use a select number of general academic and domain-specific words to create precision while speaking and writing.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Selecting and applying varied and precise vocabulary and language structures to effectively convey ideas
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Express attitude and opinions or temper statements with nuanced modal expressions (e.g., probably/certainly, should/would) and phrasing (e.g., In my opinion…).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Support opinions or persuade others by expressing appropriate/accurate reasons using detailed textual evidence (e.g., quotations or specific events from text) or relevant background knowledge about content, with light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Express attitude and opinions or temper statements with familiar modal expressions (e.g., maybe/probably, can/must).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Support opinions or persuade others by expressing appropriate/accurate reasons using some textual evidence (e.g., paraphrasing facts) or relevant background knowledge about content, with moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Express ideas and opinions or temper statements using basic modal expressions (e.g., can, will, maybe).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Support opinions by expressing appropriate/accurate reasons using textual evidence (e.g., referring to text) or relevant background knowledge about content, with substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Supporting own opinions and evaluating others' opinions in speaking and writing
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write clear and coherent summaries of texts and experiences using complete and concise sentences and key words (e.g., from notes or graphic organizers).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write longer and more detailed literary and informational texts (e.g., an explanatory text on how flashlights work) collaboratively (e.g., joint construction of texts with an adult or with peers) and independently using appropriate text organization and growing understanding of register.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write increasingly concise summaries of texts and experiences using complete sentences and key words (e.g., from notes or graphic organizers).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write longer literary and informational texts (e.g., an explanatory text on how flashlights work) collaboratively (e.g., joint construction of texts with an adult or with peers) and with increasing independence using appropriate text organization.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write brief summaries of texts and experiences using complete sentences and key words (e.g., from notes or graphic organizers).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Write short literary and informational texts (e.g., a description of a flashlight) collaboratively (e.g., joint construction of texts with an adult or with peers) and sometimes independently.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Writing literary and informational texts to present, describe, and explain ideas and information, using appropriate technology
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver oral presentations on a variety of topics in a variety of content areas (e.g., retelling a story, explaining a science process, reporting on a current event, recounting a memorable experience, and so on), with light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver longer oral presentations on a variety of topics and content areas (e.g., retelling a story, explaining a science process, reporting on a current event, recounting a memorable experience, and so on), with moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Plan and deliver brief oral presentations on a variety of topics and content areas (e.g., retelling a story, explaining a science process, reporting on a current event, recounting a memorable experience, and so on), with substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Expressing information and ideas in formal oral presentations on academic topics
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Productive (creation of oral presentations and written texts)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how different words with related meanings (e.g., fun versus entertaining versus thrilling, possibly versus certainly) and figurative language produce shades of meaning and different effects on the audience.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how different words with similar meanings (e.g., describing a character as smart versus an expert) and figurative language (e.g., as big as a whale) produce shades of meaning and different effects on the audience.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Distinguish how different words with similar meanings produce different effects on the audience (e.g., describing a character's actions as whined versus said).
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Analyzing how writers and speakers use vocabulary and other language resources for specific purposes (to explain, persuade, entertain, etc.) depending on modality, text type, purpose, audience, topic, and content area
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe how well writers and speakers use specific language resources to support an opinion or present an idea (e.g., the clarity or appealing nature of language used to present evidence), with prompting and light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe how well writers or speakers use specific language resources to support an opinion or present an idea (e.g., whether the vocabulary or phrasing used to provide evidence is strong enough), with prompting and moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe the specific language writers or speakers use to present or support an idea (e.g., the specific vocabulary or phrasing used to provide evidence), with prompting and substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Evaluating how well writers and speakers use language to support ideas and opinions with details or reasons depending on modality, text type, purpose, audience, topic, and content area
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use knowledge of morphology (e.g., affixes, roots, and base words) and linguistic context to determine the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words on familiar and new topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., pollination), and text elements (main idea, character traits, event sequence, and the like) in detail based on close reading of a variety of grade-level texts, with light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use knowledge of morphology (e.g., affixes, roots, and base words), linguistic context, and reference materials to determine the meaning of unknown words on familiar topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., animal migration), and text elements (main idea, central message, and the like) in greater detail based on close reading of a variety of grade-level texts, with moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Use knowledge of frequently used affixes (e.g., un-, mis-) and linguistic context, reference materials, and visual cues to determine the meaning of unknown words on familiar topics.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Describe ideas, phenomena (e.g., volcanic eruptions), and text elements (main idea, characters, events, and the like) based on close reading of a select set of grade-level texts, with substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Reading closely literary and informational texts and viewing multimedia to determine how meaning is conveyed explicitly and implicitly through language
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening of read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering detailed questions, with minimal prompting and light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening of read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering detailed questions, with occasional prompting and moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Demonstrate active listening of read-alouds and oral presentations by asking and answering basic questions, with prompting and substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Listening actively to spoken English in a range of social and academic contexts
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interpretive (comprehension and analysis of written and spoken texts)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Adjust language choices according to purpose, task (e.g., facilitating a science experiment), and audience, with light support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Adjust language choices according to purpose (e.g., persuading, entertaining), task (e.g., telling a story versus explaining a science experiment), and audience, with moderate support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Adjust language choices according to social setting (e.g., playground, classroom) and audience (e.g., peers, teacher), with substantial support.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Adapting language choices to various contexts (based on task, purpose, audience, and text type)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Negotiate with or persuade others in conversations using a variety of learned phrases (e.g., That's a good idea. However…), as well as open responses, in order to gain and/or hold the floor, provide counterarguments, elaborate on an idea, and so on.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Negotiate with or persuade others in conversations using an expanded set of learned phrases (e.g., I agree with X, but…), as well as open responses, in order to gain and/or hold the floor, provide counterarguments, and so on.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Negotiate with or persuade others in conversations using basic learned phrases (e.g., I think…), as well as open responses, in order to gain and/or hold the floor.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Offering and supporting opinions and negotiating with others in communicative exchanges
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with peers on joint writing projects of a variety of longer informational and literary texts, using technology where appropriate for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with peers on joint writing projects of longer informational and literary texts, using technology where appropriate for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborate with peers on joint writing projects of short informational and literary texts, using technology where appropriate for publishing, graphics, and the like.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interacting with others in written English in various communicative forms (print, communicative technology, and multimedia)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to class, group, and partner discussions, including sustained dialogue, by following turn-taking rules, asking relevant questions, affirming others, adding relevant information, building on responses, and providing useful feedback.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to class, group, and partner discussions, including sustained dialogue, by following turn-taking rules, asking relevant questions, affirming others, and adding relevant information.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Contribute to conversations and express ideas by asking and answering yes-no and wh- questions and responding using short phrases.
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Exchanging information and ideas with others through oral collaborative conversations on a range of social and academic topics
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Collaborative (engagement in dialogue with others)
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)

Standard_Text: Interacting in Meaningful Ways
Subject: English Language Development (2012-)
